Graphical abstract Cu/SSZ-13 SCR catalysts have been extensively studied in the past decade or so. Hydrothermal stability of these catalysts has been identified as the most important criterion for application. In this perspective, we describe recent atomic-level understanding of their hydrothermal stability. In particular, electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) is shown to rather accurately quantify isolated Cu(II) ions and CuO clusters in fresh and aged catalysts to demonstrate the remarkable hydrothermal stability for Cu2+ ions located in 6-membered ring windows, and the conversion of [Cu(OH)]+ ions in Chabazite cages to CuO clusters. The hydrothermal stability difference of the two isolated Cu(II) ions is confirmed with DFT simulations and the conversion of [Cu(OH)]+ to CuO is proposed to involve formation, migration and condensation of Cu(OH)2 intermediates. The structural destructive role of CuO clusters is attributed to mesopore formation from their migration, which more severely damages the catalysts than dealumination. Finally, perspectives are given on new strategies for low-temperature NOx removal, rational design and refinement of Cu/SSZ-13, and development of new Cu/zeolite SCR catalysts with even better performance than the state-of-the-art Cu/SSZ-13. Keywords Chabazite SSZ-13 Hydrothermal aging Selective catalytic reduction NOx 1 Introduction Ammonia (or urea) selective catalytic reduction (NH3-SCR) over Cu and Fe-exchanged zeolite catalysts has become the leading NOx abatement technique for diesel powered lean combustion vehicles, showing important advantages over the other commercialized lean NOx abatement technique, i.e., NOx storage-reduction (NSR) [1–4]. These include enhanced robustness, low cost, and the wide range of applicability from light to heavy duty vehicles. The higher robustness of SCR over NSR can be understood from two aspects: the capacity to withstand harsher hydrothermal aging conditions, and higher tolerance to sulfur poisoning. The former is attributed to the important discovery in recent years that small pore SSZ-13 zeolite, after Cu- and/or Fe-ion exchange, can withstand harsh hydrothermal aging at 800 °C and above, enabling long term usability as part of the diesel engine aftertreatment system [5–7]. Some other properly formulated zeolites, in particular Fe-exchange Beta zeolite, appear to also meet some of the criteria for industrial applications [8,9]. Tolerance to sulfur poisoning is, to a large extent, intrinsic to the nature of the materials. All three key components of a NSR catalyst, i.e., the support, the basic oxide NOx storage phase and the noble metal are vulnerable to sulfur poisoning. As such, this technique only finds applications in aftertreatment of exhausts from combustion of ultra-low sulfur fuels [10]. In contrast, Cu and Fe-exchanged zeolites are naturally more tolerant to sulfur poisoning. On the basis of recent studies, sulfur poisoning of the current state-of-the-art Cu/SSZ-13 catalysts can even be regarded as completely reversible, where periodic high-temperature deSOx treatments fully recover catalytic performance of the catalysts [11]. Despite its robustness, degradation of the SSZ-13 support, e.g., dealumination and surface area/pore volume loss, and transformation of Cu from SCR active to inactive forms, do occur during hydrothermal aging of Cu/SSZ-13 [12–19]. Such irreversible changes account for catalyst performance loss during on-road applications. This is because during active regeneration events of a diesel engine exhaust aftertreatment system, e.g., deSOx and combustion of soot accumulated in diesel particulate filter, the SCR catalyst is unavoidably exposed to a hydrothermal aging environment, i.e., elevated temperatures typically in excess of 500 ºC in the presence of large quantities of water vapor [19]. As such, hydrothermal stability can be considered as the most important criterion for the evaluation of long-term stability of an industrial SCR catalyst. In the following, important discoveries on Cu/SSZ-13 SCR hydrothermal stability are summarized, followed by our personal perspectives on challenges and future research directions. 2 Cu/SSZ-13 structure The Chabazite structure that SSZ-13 adopts is constructed by stacking double 6-membered ring (6MR) prisms in an AABBCCAA sequence. This allows formation of large CHA cavities accessible through a three-dimensional 8MR pore system as displayed in Fig. 1 a [7,20]. Each hexagonal unit cell contains two sections: a large CHA cage and a double 6MR prism, built with 36 symmetry-equivalent tetrahedral (T) atoms (Si or Al atoms) and 72 oxygen atoms. The CHA framework can be constructed at various Si/Al ratios from 1 to infinity. The pore openings of SSZ-13 are ∼3.8 Å, allowing free transport of all NH3-SCR reactants and products. Possible extraframework exchange positions for SSZ-13 are presented in Fig. 1b. These include (1) center of the double 6MR prism (position I), (2) next to the window of 6MR (position II), (3) along the three-fold axis (position III), and (4) next to the window of 8MR (position IV) [20]. It is now generally agreed that isolated Cu ions (i.e., the active sites for NH3-SCR in this catalyst) only occupy positions II and IV in dehydrated catalysts [21]. More details are as follows. Properly ion-exchanged Cu/SSZ-13 in the as-prepared ambient form, especially at relatively low Cu loadings, only contains extraframework isolated Cu(II) ions, i.e., Cu2+ ions that are balanced by paired framework charges (as Cu2+-2Z, where Z represents a framework negative charge), and [Cu(OH)]+ ions that are balanced by a single framework charge (as [Cu(OH)]+-Z) [21]. In fully hydrated samples, these ions are solvated by H2O ligands and present as [Cu(H2O)6]2+ and [Cu(OH)(H2O)5]+ located in the CHA cages [22]. In the dehydrated form, they convert to “naked” Cu2+-2Z and [Cu(OH)]+-Z ions coordinated with zeolite lattice oxygens in windows of 6MRs and 8MRs, respectively. More specifically, the thermodynamically most stable Cu2+-2Z ions locate in windows of 6MRs, adopting 3 or 4 Cu-O coordination. [Cu(OH)]+-Z ions locate in 8MRs, adopting 3 Cu-O coordination (two framework O together with OH) [21]. Note that an isolated Cu(II) ion can in principle be located also at the center of the double 6MR prism (position I in Fig. 1b) and adopt 6 Cu-O coordination (i.e., with 3 O in each 6MR). However, this hypothetically stable location for Cu(II) has not been confirmed either experientially or computationally. Remaining Brønsted acid sites are also critical for SCR because these are largely responsible for ammonia storage [23]. [24] and Ye et al. [25] demonstrated higher hydrothermal stability of Cu/SSZ-13 (in the powder form) in comparison to medium and large-pore Cu/zeolite catalysts. Hydrothermal aging effects for fully formulated (i.e., washcoated) catalysts were also reported about the same time [13,26]. Some of these studies demonstrated that hydrothermal aging causes SCR performance deterioration, including decrease in low-temperature NOx conversion rates and high-temperature SCR selectivities [12,13,26]. However others did not observe marked difference between fresh and aged samples [24,25]. In these early studies, compositions of the Cu/SSZ-13 catalysts were largely fixed so that many atomic details cannot be derived. As an exception, the work by Fickel et al. [12] made the first effort to vary Si/Al ratio and Cu loading, and demonstrated that a catalyst with high Cu loading (Cu/Al = 0.35) has lower hydrothermal stability than a catalyst with moderate Cu loading (Cu/Al = 0.28). The authors postulated, on the basis of prior hydrothermal aging studies of Cu/ZSM-5, that high amounts of copper in the zeolite make the framework unstable, and at high temperatures copper aluminate and copper oxide species form that can break apart the structure. The first much more thorough hydrothermal stability study on samples with varying Si/Al and Cu/Al ratios were conducted by Nam and coworkers [14]. In this study, catalysts with Si/Al ratios of 14, 20 and 25, Cu/Al ratios ranging from 0.15 to 0.51 were used and three hydrothermal aging temperatures (650, 750 and 850 ºC) were chosen. This work confirmed the discovery of Fickel et al. [12] that high Cu loading is detrimental to hydrothermal stability. Furthermore, the authors for the first time demonstrated hydrothermal stability difference of the two isolated Cu(II) ions, i.e., higher stability of Cu2+-2Z in comparison to [Cu(OH)]+-Z. The authors also attempted to quantify different Cu species with H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) on the basis that [Cu(OH)]+-Z reduces at lower temperatures than Cu2+-2Z [27]. However, extensive overlapping in reduction states of various Cu-containing species makes this technique, at best, semi-quantitative. Much more recently, Han et al. revisited Cu/Al ratio [15] and Si/Al ratio [16] effects on hydrothermal stability of Cu/SSZ-13. Besides confirming previous findings that catalyst degradation becomes more severe with increasing aging temperature and Cu/Al ratio, the authors also found that catalyst degradation becomes more severe with increasing Si/Al ratio. 4 Case studies on atomic-level understanding of hydrothermal aging effects The following points/questions are critical for a better understanding of hydrothermal aging effects for Cu/SSZ-13 at an atomic level. These include: (1) changes to the SSZ-13 support, including its bulk properties (crystallinity, surface area, pore distribution, etc.), but particularly the extent of dealumination; (2) transformation of Cu species, including repositioning of the active sites, and conversion of Cu from SCR active to inactive forms; (3) how such changes affect SCR performance and long-term stability of SCR catalysts; (4) how understanding such changes lead to new knowledge on designing better catalysts; and (5) whether or not key descriptors can be derived from such studies that link accelerated lab-scale hydrothermal aging to catalyst performance under on-road applications. Two case studies are shown below to demonstrate some of the efforts in elucidating these questions. 4.1 Cu transformation at relatively low aging temperatures Recently, Luo et al.[19] hydrothermally aged a state-of-the-art industrial Cu/SSZ-13 catalyst with Si/Al = 9.5 and Cu/Al = 0.3 at 600 ºC for varying durations from 1 to 100 h. Following this aging protocol, NH3 temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) was performed to titrate Cu and Brønsted acid sites, where NH3 adsorption was carried out at 150 ºC to saturate both Lewis (i.e., Cu ions) and Brønsted acid sites. The results are shown in Fig. 2 . The desorption state above 400 ºC is readily attributed to NH3 desorption from Brønsted acid sites, while the state below 300 ºC is assigned to NH3 desorption from Cu ions [27]. It is clear from the figure that the number of Brønsted acid sites decreases with increasing aging duration. However, as will be shown below, an aging temperature of 600 ºC causes barely any dealumination as determined from 27Al nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR). On the basis that for SSZ-13, each framework Al generates ∼1 Brønsted acid site [28], Brønsted acidity loss during aging is best described by Cu ion transformation, i.e., conversion of [Cu(OH)]+-Z to Cu2+-2Z: (1) C u O H + - Z + H + - Z = C u 2 + - 2 Z + H 2 O This notion is fully consistent with NH3/Cu ratio quantifications using the TPD data, where it was found that at the NH3 adsorption temperature 150 ºC, ∼2 molecules of NH3 adsorbs on Cu2+-2Z and ∼1 molecule of NH3 adsorbs on [Cu(OH)]+-Z. The fact that 1 molecule of NH3 adsorbs on 1 Brønsted acid site nicely explains the largely invariant NH3 yields as a function of aging time as shown in Fig. 2. This study demonstrates an important fact that in freshly prepared Cu/SSZ-13 catalysts, thermodynamically less stable [Cu(OH)]+-Z can populate prior to saturation of more stable Cu2+-2Z due to kinetic stabilization [29]. However, given enough duration and thermal energy for relaxation (e.g., during hydrothermal aging), [Cu(OH)]+-Z can gradually convert to thermodynamically more stable Cu2+-2Z as long as unoccupied paired Al sites are available. This study, therefore, provides a justification of a common industrial practice of “degreening” a SCR catalyst prior to its first use. This “degreening” process is essentially a short period of hydrothermal aging treatment at relatively low temperatures (e.g., 600–700 ºC), serving to stabilize a SCR catalyst by converting some Cu ions into thermodynamically more stable forms. 4.2 Temperature dependence on hydrothermal aging As discussed above, hydrothermal aging induced changes to the SSZ-13 support can be assessed by measuring bulk properties including crystallinity, surface area, pore distribution, etc. However to gain further details about structural degradation of the SSZ-13 support, local environments of framework Al and Si must be examined; the best technique in this regard is solid-state 27Al and 29Si NMR [18,27]. Transformation of Cu species, on the other hand, can be qualitatively and semi-quantitatively examined with chemical titrations (e.g., NO chemisorption FTIR) and H2-TPR. Recently, Song et al.[17] demonstrated that electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) can be used to rather precisely quantify Cu2+-2Z, [Cu(OH)]+-Z and CuO clusters for Cu/SSZ-13 samples following any stage of hydrothermal treatment. As will be shown below, this allows us to gain some unprecedented information on Cu transformation. In this case study, a Cu/SSZ-13 catalyst with Si/Al = 12 and Cu loading of 2.1%, hydrothermally aged at varying temperatures from 550 to 900 °C is used to describe how quantitative dealumination and Cu-ion transformation information is derived. Fig. 3 a presents 27Al NMR spectra of the fresh and aged samples. Note that aged samples are denoted as “HTA-T” here, where “HTA” represents hydrothermal aging and “T” the aging temperature in Celsius. The features at 57.5 ppm (referenced to an AlCl3 solution) are attributed to framework, tetrahedral Al and signals at ∼0 ppm are assigned to extraframework, octahedral Al. Since these spectra are both sample weight and measurement time normalized, extents of dealumination can be readily obtained by ratioing framework Al signal areas of the HTA samples against that of the fresh catalyst. From the numbers marked adjacent to each spectrum, it is seen that dealumination is highly temperature dependent. For example, the HTA-550/600 samples experience essentially no dealumination, whereas the HTA-900 sample has ∼40% framework Al loss. The corresponding 29Si NMR spectra are displayed in Fig. 3b. The fresh catalyst contains two framework tetrahedral Si (Q4) features: one at −105 ppm (referenced to tetramethylsilane, TMS) attributed to tetrahedral Si with three Si and one Al neighbors (i.e., Si(OSi)3(OAl)) and one at −111 ppm to tetrahedral Si with four Si neighbors (i.e., Si(OSi)4) [30]. At hydrothermal aging temperatures of 650 °C and higher, the −105 ppm feature progressively declines, consistent with catalyst dealumination shown in Fig. 3a. Note that these spectra were acquired on a high resolution 850 MHz instrument; the high quality of these spectra thus allows meaningful signal lineshape analysis. For example, as shown in Fig. 3c, full-width at half-maximum (FWHM) of the fresh catalyst framework Al signal is apparently higher than those of the HTA-550/600 samples, suggesting higher extents of framework Al distortion for the former, likely resulting from organic template combustion during SSZ-13 substrate preparation and during solution ion-exchange steps in catalyst synthesis. This type of Al distortion apparently diminishes during hydrothermal aging at relatively low temperatures, due presumably to lattice relaxation. Again, this result provides the same justification for the industrial practice of “degreening” an SCR catalyst prior to its first use, since this treatment eliminates framework distortion, which is expected to mitigate H2O attack and enhance catalyst durability. However when aging temperature becomes sufficiently high (∼700 ºC and above), framework distortion caused by dealumination wins over lattice relaxation, causing framework Al FWHM to increase again with increasing temperature. The result shown in Fig. 3c thus indicates that the FWHM of 27Al NMR can be used as a descriptor for structural degradation. However, Al NMR signals can be influenced differently by different treatments (e.g., with different gas exposures). For such a method to be useful, besides high resolution instruments, sample treatment should also be conducted in controlled manners. To quantify Cu2+-2Z, [Cu(OH)]+-Z and CuO clusters in these samples, the fresh and aged samples were examined with EPR in both hydrated and dehydrated forms at cryogenic temperatures, and the result is displayed in Fig. 4 . This quantification is based on the facts that Cu2+-2Z ions are EPR active in both hydrated (i.e., as [Cu(H2O)6]2+) and dehydrated forms, CuO clusters are always EPR silent due to antiferromagnetic effects [31], and [Cu(OH)]+-Z ions are EPR active when hydrated (as [Cu(OH)(H2O)5]+), but become EPR silent in the dehydrated form due to a pseudo Jahn-Teller effect, i.e., absorbed microwave energy by [Cu(OH)]+-Z dissipates too rapidly for the time scale of EPR [32]. The results show that with increasing aging temperature, [Cu(OH)]+-Z content monotonically decreases while CuO content monotonically increases. Cu2+-2Z content first increases, reaching a highest value of ∼1.5 wt.% in the HTA-700 sample, then slightly declines and stabilizes at ∼1.2 wt.% in samples aged at higher temperatures. This quantification confirms the conclusion made by Nam and coworkers [14] that Cu2+-2Z has higher hydrothermal stability than [Cu(OH)]+-Z. Furthermore, detailed Cu transformation pathways during hydrothermal aging are now clear: at aging temperatures ≤700 °C, a portion of [Cu(OH)]+-Z ions gradually convert to Cu2+-2Z according to Eq. (1) shown above, and a portion convert to CuO clusters. Reaction mechanism for the latter transformation is not fully known at present. Song et al. [17] proposed that during hydrothermal aging, [Cu(OH)]+-Z first undergoes a hydrolysis reaction in the presence of water to form a mobile Cu(OH)2 species (Eq. (2)), the latter then migrates and agglomerates, eventually to form CuO clusters (Eq. (3)). (2) C u O H + - Z + H 2 O = C u O H 2 + H + - Z (3) n C u O H 2 = C u O n + n H 2 O Note that this mechanism proposal has not yet been verified experimentally. However, there exists some strong indirect evidence for its justification. First, since a charged [Cu(NH3)2]+ species has been proven to transport readily through the Chabazite pores [22], transport of the charge neutral Cu(OH)2 should also be facile both energetically and sterically. Second, the much higher hydrothermal stability for Cu2+-2Z in comparison to [Cu(OH)]+-Z indicates much higher hydrolysis activation energies for the former. This, indeed, has been confirmed via calculations with density functional theory [17]. In particular, Cu(OH)2 formation from [Cu(OH)]+-Z requires a single hydrolysis step with a Gibbs free energy barrier of 155 kJ/mol. Removing Cu2+-2Z from the cationic position as Cu(OH)2, in contrast, requires two hydrolysis steps. Even though the first step is less demanding (energy cost 92 kJ/mol), the second hydrolysis step has a formidable energy barrier of 233 kJ/mol. More details about the DFT calculations, especially simulated structures of the different states can be found elsewhere [17]. These results provide a good explanation why Cu2+-2Z is hydrothermally so much more stable than [Cu(OH)]+-Z. Even for the latter, the rather high hydrolysis activation energy is consistent with the fact that CuO formation requires high aging temperatures (Fig. 4). 4.3 Nature of the CuO species, and its structural destructing role Unlike Cu2+-2Z and [Cu(OH)]+-Z species where their locations and local environments have been extensively studied and well documented, the nature of CuO clusters in hydrothermally aged Cu/SSZ-13 is only poorly understood. Some recent efforts have been exerted to better understand their sizes, locations and local environments, yet with limited success. Notably, Song et al. [17] utilized high resolution scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) trying to image Cu aggregates in aged Cu/SSZ-13, yet failed to identify any CuO clusters. However using the same technique, FexOy clusters measuring ∼1 nm in size were indeed observed in aged Fe/SSZ-13 [33]. The undetectability via STEM suggests much smaller sizes of the CuO clusters, and they do not seem to reside on the external surfaces of SSZ-13 which will otherwise render them relatively ready to image. The latter statement was indeed confirmed via measurements with X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), where the lack of Cu and Al surface enrichment in hydrothermally aged Cu/SSZ-13 suggests that Cu and Al that detach from their fresh sample locations do not diffuse to the zeolite external surface [17]. From such indirect evidence, it can be postulated that CuO clusters in hydrothermally aged Cu/SSZ-13 are very small, and they reside in Chabazite pores and channels. Numerous prior studies have confirmed that hydrothermal aging of Cu/zeolites induces two important changes that deteriorate catalytic performance and stability: zeolite dealumination and isolated Cu ion agglomeration to CuO [34–37]. It is highly relevant and interesting to elucidate whether or not CuO species and detached Al interact with each other to form copper aluminate during aging. On the basis of similar reduction temperatures of CuAl2O4 and aged Cu/ZSM-5 in H2-TPR, Yan et al. [36] suggested CuAl2O4 formation from CuO species and detached Al. Via XANES spectra analysis, Vennestrøm et al. [37] suggested that the Cu-Al phase formed in aged Cu/ZSM-5 is similar to the CuAl2O4 spinel in terms of reducibility, but not in terms of local coordination even though an Al/Cu ratio of 2 is found. The lower symmetry of the Cu-Al phase may also be attributed to very small clusters of Cu and Al that would fit inside the micropores of the zeolites. In a most recent study using atom probe tomography (APT), Schmidt et al. [38] confirmed formation of an agglomerated phase of Cu aluminate with an Al/Cu ratio of 2 in hydrothermally aged Cu/ZSM-5. In aged Cu/SSZ-13, Cu and Al clustering was also observed, however with much lowered extent, and unknown stoichiometry. From these previous studies, it can be postulated that CuO and detached Al indeed tend to interact with each other during hydrothermal aging. However this chemistry appears to be controlled by diffusion of the two components and spatial limitations. CuAl2O4 spinel with long-range order is only expected when the zeolite structural damage becomes extensive. With limited zeolite structural degradation and hindered CuO and Al transport, small CuAl2O4-like species with poor crystallinity, or Al enriched CuO clusters should form. For the structural rigid Cu/SSZ-13, we suggest formation of Al enriched CuO clusters during hydrothermal aging, unless aging conditions become so severe that extensive structure collapse occurs. Since zeolite dealumination and CuO formation occur simultaneously during hydrothermal aging, it is difficult to elucidate which factor is more detrimental to catalyst structural integrity. In an early study by Kharas et al. [34] on stability of Cu/ZSM-5, the authors postulated that pore volume losses of this catalyst is not caused by coking or dealumination, but rather CuO crystallites growth in the zeolite bulk. As these crystallites exceed critical sizes imposed by zeolite structural constraint, copper sintering requires local destruction of the zeolite. For Cu/SSZ-13 catalysts, work by Fickel et al. [12] and Kim et al. [14] clearly established that high Cu loaded samples have lower hydrothermal stability. Note from discussions above that high Cu loaded samples contain higher concentrations of [Cu(OH)]+-Z which agglomerates to form CuO during aging, it appears logical to suggest that for Cu/SSZ-13, structural degradation is primarily caused by the presence of CuO. This statement is also corroborated by a recent study by Kovarik et al. [33], where the authors discovered that a Fe/SSZ-13 catalyst can maintain perfect structural integrity even upon ∼80% of dealumination. This study therefore suggests that dealumination alone may not be the main cause of structural degradation for Cu/SSZ-13. To further demonstrate the structural degradation role of CuO clusters, a pore distribution analysis of the fresh, HTA-700 and HTA-800 samples (Si/Al = 12, Cu loading = 2.1 wt.%) were conducted with Ar absorption isotherm. Note that using Ar as a probe molecule instead of the commonly used N2 avoids errors caused by quadrupolar moment of the latter, thus increasing accuracy for pore analysis [39–41]. As shown in Fig. 5 a, in comparison to the fresh sample, hydrothermal aging causes decrease in total micropores, however imposes no effect on micropore size. This is consistent with the structural rigidity of SSZ-13. From Fig. 5b, however, amount of mesopore increases dramatically in the aged samples. Particularly, in comparison to HTA-700, the amount of mesopores that are ≤4 nm increases dramatically in the HTA-800 sample. From the pore volume quantification results shown in Table 1 , it is clearly evident that mesopore formation in the HTA-700 sample is not at the expense of the micropore volume. Presumably, mesopore formation at this temperature is due primarily to dealumination, commonly known to occur during hydrothermal aging of zeolites [42]. However for the HTA-800 sample, the “extra” mesopore volume above that of the HTA-700 sample is due almost entirely to micropore destruction; this is certainly attributable to the generation of mesopores that are ≤4 nm in the HTA-800 sample (Fig. 5b). These findings lead to an important hypothesis that the structural destruction role for CuO clusters is the creation of new pores/channels due to their migration. The accumulation of such new voids destabilize the catalyst and eventually leads to structural collapse. It is readily anticipated that creation of such voids is dependent on Cu content of the catalysts, aging time and duration, where catalysts with higher Cu loadings, aged at higher temperatures and longer durations degrade more. This notion is fully consistent with experimental findings [5,13,14,24,43]. We note that this new explanation on Cu/zeolite structural destruction due to migration of CuO clusters appears to more accurately describe their destructive role than the original explanation by Kharas et al. [34] that it is the physical size of the CuO clusters alone that destructs zeolites. Since most Cu/zeolite SCR catalysts only contain a few percent of Cu; the total volumes of the CuO clusters alone can only account for destruction of a small portion of the zeolite pores. Without their continuous migration, it is difficult to justify the catastrophic destruction role for CuO at elevated aging temperatures. Finally, Al incorporation into CuO clusters, as is discussed earlier, is anticipated to enlarge the CuO clusters, making them more destructive. It is also interesting to note that Fe/zeolites, for example Fe/ZSM-5 and Fe/Beta, typically offer better hydrothermal stability than their Cu counterparts [44–47]. It can be postulated that FexOy clusters formed during hydrothermal aging have much lower mobility, and are thus much less destructive than the highly mobile CuO clusters. From TEM imaging, FexOy clusters measuring ∼1nm in dimension were detected in aged Fe/SSZ-13 [33], whereas CuO clusters are undetectable in aged Cu/SSZ-13 [17]. It is likely, therefore, their size difference plays a decisive role in their destructive capacity. The larger, less mobile FexOy clusters only cause local destruction of unit cells because of their physical sizes; whereas the smaller, highly mobile CuO clusters cause long range destruction. 4.4 Structure-activity correlations Activity and selectivity are the most important criteria for a SCR catalyst in application. Under normal on-road operation conditions (∼200–350 ºC), most fresh Cu/zeolite SCR catalysts perform satisfactorily with very high NOx conversion rates and selectivities. Therefore, high SCR rates at low temperatures (≤200 ºC), high SCR selectivities at high temperatures (≥350 ºC) and low N2O formation really distinguish good SCR catalysts from bad ones. In the study by Song et al. [17], standard SCR (4NO + 4NH3 + O2 = 4N2 + 6H2O) performance for the fresh and HTA Cu/SSZ-13 catalysts described above was investigated with both light-off measurements and testing at low NOx conversions under kinetic control [17]. Three points are worth noting: (1) in the low-temperature regime, reaction rates decrease with increasing aging temperature of the catalysts. From the quantification results of Cu species shown in Fig. 4, this is readily attributed to the loss of SCR active isolated [Cu(OH)]+-Z sites. (2) SCR selectivities (i.e., ratios between NOx and NH3 conversions) maintain excellent below ∼350 ºC suggesting the essential absence of the side reaction NH3 oxidation by O2 (4NH3 + 3O2 = 2N2 + 6H2O). This does not mean that the catalysts cannot catalyze NH3 oxidation below ∼350 ºC; in the presence of NOx, this side reaction is essentially completely suppressed by the much faster SCR reaction. (3) In the high-temperature regime, NH3 oxidation becomes non-negligible causing SCR selectivities to decrease with increasing reaction temperature. Clearly this is due primarily to the presence of CuO clusters. These species are much more active in O2 activation than isolated Cu ions and are thus much less selective for SCR. For hydrothermally aged SCR catalysts with higher Cu loadings, high temperature SCR selectivity loss can become very severe due to the presence of large amounts of CuO clusters [13]. To gain more details on reactivity of individual Cu active sites, Song et al. [17] also performed standard SCR testing under kinetic control. The Arrhenius equation, k = r [ N O ] 0 = A e - E a R T , was then used for estimating pre-exponential factors (A) and apparent activation energies (Ea), where k is the rate constant and [NO]0 the molar concentration of NO in the feed [48]. These kinetic parameters are listed in Table 2 . The apparent activation energies are typical for standard NH3-SCR over Cu/SSZ-13 under kinetic control [49,50], and the similar Ea values among the catalysts indicate similar active centers and reaction pathways. In other words, hydrothermal aging does not alter the nature of the active sites in this catalyst. This is consistent with the fact that isolated Cu ions are the active centers in these catalysts, and the newly formed Cu moieties in the aged samples do not catalyze low-temperature SCR. In contrast, pre-exponential factors change dramatically with hydrothermal aging. The moderately aged HTA-600/650/700 samples display pre-exponential factors two orders of magnitude lower than the fresh catalyst, while the heavily aged HTA-750/800/900 ones display prefactors three orders of magnitude lower. This indicates that effective collisions between reactants and Cu active sites decrease markedly with increasing aging temperature, perhaps as a result of the chabazite framework exhibiting stronger confinement of the Cu active sites with increasing aging temperature. It has been established recently that O2 activation by a pair of [CuI(NH3)2]+ intermediates is a key kinetically relevant step for low-temperature standard SCR [51,52]. While [CuI(NH3)2]+ intermediates have the highest mobility among all Cu-containing species under low-temperate SCR [53], their mobility is still confined by framework negative charges [22]. It is highly anticipated that framework Al distribution influences formation of the [CuI(NH3)2]+-O2-[CuI(NH3)2]+ complex. The decrease in pre-exponential factors with increasing aging temperature (Table 2) appear to justify the notion that [CuI(NH3)2]+-O2-[CuI(NH3)2]+ formation becomes more difficult with increasing aging temperature due to restriction of [CuI(NH3)2]+ mobility. This notion can be further corroborated by calculating turnover frequencies (TOFs) of individual Cu ions in low-temperature SCR. Using reaction rate results collected under kinetic control, and isolated Cu ion quantification results shown in Fig. 4, TOFs at low temperatures (e.g., 150 ºC) can be readily calculated and compared. The ∼2 time decrease in TOFs from samples populated with similar amounts of Cu2+-2Z and [Cu(OH)]+-Z to samples contain primarily Cu2+-2Z (Fig. 4) indicates more facile formation of the [CuI(NH3)2]+-O2-[CuI(NH3)2]+ intermediate for the former case, suggesting stronger restriction on [CuI(NH3)2]+ mobility in proximity of paired Al sites within the same 6MR. In other words, in comparison to Cu2+-2Z, [Cu(OH)]+-Z is slightly more active in catalyzing low-temperature SCR. 5 Perspectives on challenges and future directions Although the NH3-SCR technology has recently been successfully introduced into practical applications in diesel powered vehicles, there are several challenges facing the catalysis community: (1) new high efficiency combustion strategies produce exhausts at ever decreasing temperatures. For example, petroleum-electric hybrid vehicles keep gaining popularity in recent years. However the engines undergo cold-start operation much more frequently than traditional internal combustion engines. It is estimated that the exhaust temperature of future lean-burn engines under normal driving conditions will not exceed 150 ºC. (2) New regulations require ever decreasing levels of harmful emissions from internal combustion engines. Such challenges have been described in detail elsewhere [54]. Here we only briefly discuss three of the important issues that are relevant to new development or refinement of current SCR catalysts. 5.1 Low temperature NOx removal There are two major thrusts regarding the “low temperature challenge” in emission control catalysis. First, a large fraction of the NOx released during the full operating cycle of an engine emitted during the cold-start period. Second, current commercial NOx reduction techniques are poorly effective when the catalyst temperature is lower than that required for efficient NOx reduction (≥200 ºC). Two possible solutions are provided and discussed here. The first one is the development of SCR catalysts that are already highly efficient at 150 ºC. PNNL, Cummins Inc. and Johnson-Matthey Inc. having been collaborating in the past 3 years developing a sustained low-temperature NOx reduction (SLTNR) system that is capable of 90% NOx removal at a SCR inlet temperature of 150 ºC. Key aspects of this new technology include: (1) the utilization of fast SCR (NO + NO2 + 2NH3 = N2 + H2O) instead of standard SCR to boost low-temperature NOx conversion. To generate sufficient amounts of NO2 (ideal NO2/NOx = 0.5), a diesel oxidation catalyst (DOC) bed, placed upper stream of the SCR bed, was used to combust residual hydrocarbons and oxidize NO to NO2. Hydrocarbon combustion is critical here since HCs can reduce NO2 back to NO. (2) The development of a novel Fe/zeolite catalyst that is highly active for fast SCR, yet with minimal NH4NO3 inhibition effect. The latter was achieved by minimizing ammonia storage capacity of the catalyst to inhibit NH3 and nitrate interactions to form NH4NO3. This is highly important since NH4NO3, with its low reactivity at low temperatures and a melting point of ∼180 ºC, can severely poison the SCR catalyst by blocking reactants to access active sites at 150 ºC. To minimize ammonia storage capacity, residual Brønsted acid site density must be lowered. This was achieved by increasing Fe loading (i.e., ion-exchange level) of the catalysts, or by hydrothermal treatments to partially dealuminate the catalysts. (3) The development of a novel urea delivery system that generates and delivers ultrafine urea droplets at 150 ºC. To avoid urea deposition at the delivery tubes, a heater with minimal energy penalty was also designed to heat up these tubes. Both laboratory engine test and test on a city bus indicated great potential for this technique to be commercialized that, for the first time, achieves high NOx conversions at temperatures 50–100 ºC lower than current SCR catalysts. Another emerging technology to solve the cold start problem is the use of passive NOx adsorbers (PNAs). These adsorber materials are tasked to remove all the NOx coming from the engine at start-up, store and subsequently release them at temperatures high enough for the downstream SCR catalysts to operate. These adsorbers must effectively adsorb NOx from the gas stream and bind them with intermediate strength so that they would only be released at the right temperatures. In contrast to the NSR technique with repeated rich-lean cycling, PNAs are designed for lean operations. The elimination of the need for the rich purging significantly enhances fuel economy and engine durability, and simplifies electronic controlling. The most efficient current PNA materials are Pd loaded zeolites [55–57]. Pd/zeolites are highly effective in adsorbing NOx at low temperatures and releasing them at moderately high temperatures (>150 ºC). Currently this is a very active area of research, as many factors strongly influencing the effectiveness of these materials need to be understood (e.g., zeolite framework structure, Pd loading, preparation methods, gas composition, etc.). This technology is briefly described here for two reasons: first, this technology is designed to operate together with the SCR technology. Second, the zeolite-based PNA materials should also survive under harsh hydrothermal aging conditions. Hydrothermal stability of these new Pd/zeolite materials is largely unexplored at present. However, lessons learned from studies with Cu and Fe/zeolites should have a high degree of applicability to the PNA materials. 5.2 Refinement of Cu/SSZ-13 From the discussions above, there exists a dilemma between low-temperature activity and high-temperature hydrothermal stability/SCR selectivity for Cu/SSZ-13 catalysts, that is, increase in low-temperature activity is almost always at the expense of decrease in high-temperature hydrothermal stability/SCR selectivity. This dilemma stems from the high SCR activity but low hydrothermal stability of [Cu(OH)]+-Z. Some rational catalyst design principles are suggested in the following on the basis of the atomic-level understanding of Cu/SSZ-13 activity and hydrothermal stability shown above. (1) On the basis that [Cu(OH)]+-Z active sites offer slightly higher turnover rates than Cu2+-2Z, increasing ion-exchange levels that populate [Cu(OH)]+-Z species to near saturation will be beneficial for the enhancement of low-temperature NOx conversions. However, catalysts thus formulated will not be hydrothermally highly stable. Therefore, high Cu-loaded catalysts are only suggested when aging temperatures exceeding ∼700 ºC are highly unexpected. (2) For optimum hydrothermal stability of Cu/SSZ-13 catalysts, preventing the formation of large amounts of CuO clusters is critical. In this case, total Cu loading must be chosen based on Si/Al ratios of the zeolite. Nam and coworkers suggested an optimum ion-exchange level of ∼70% [14]. This number should be further lowered since CuO formation is clearly the most detrimental factor, much more than dealumination, in influencing long term stability of this catalyst. Over the past decade or so, we have witnessed the change of SSZ-13 substrate Si/Al ratio from Si/Al = 17.5 for the first generation BASF catalyst [13] to Si/Al = 10 [11] for the current state-of-the-art catalyst reflects efforts for this optimization. This change is non-trivial. As suggested by Fig. 4, a lower Si/Al ratio allows for a higher percentage of Cu2+-2Z sites at similar Cu loadings, thus reducing the formation of undesired CuOx clusters during hydrothermal aging. As judged from our Cu/SSZ-13 materials synthesized in-house, lowering Si/Al ratios further to ∼6 does not lead to catalysts with inferior hydrothermal stability in comparison to catalysts with higher Si/Al ratios, as long as Cu/Al ratios are properly adjusted. Hydrothermal stability for Cu/SSZ-13 catalysts with even lower Si/Al ratios is less clear. Besides Cu/Al and Si/Al ratio adjustment, additives can also enhance durability of Cu/SSZ-13 catalysts. Two strategies, largely unexplored, are discussed here: (1) addition of alkali cocations to neutralize Brønsted acid sites, and (2) addition of metal oxides to “trap” highly mobile CuO clusters formed during hydrothermal aging. For the enhancement of high-temperature SCR selectivity, maximizing Cu2+-2Z and minimizing [Cu(OH)]+-Z is the most beneficial. In this case, no CuO is generated during hydrothermal aging to ensure excellent SCR selectivities even at SCR reaction temperatures higher than 400 ºC. However, for SSZ-13 substrates with high Si/Al ratios, such a strategy leads to catalysts with Cu loadings too low to be practical. This is because paired framework Al sites, required to stabilize Cu2+-2Z, decrease exponentially with increasing Si/Al ratio [22]. In this sense, low Si/Al ratio SSZ-13 substrates should be used to accommodate enough Cu2+-2Z sites for low-temperature activity. However, a Cu2+-2Z dominance situation at low Si/Al ratios inevitably leads to relatively high residual Brønsted acid site densities that are vulnerable to dealumination. We have shown previously that for low Cu-loaded Cu/SSZ-13 (∼1 wt%) with Si/Al = 6, introduction of alkali cocations that neutralize some Brønsted acid sites can pose benefits to catalyst hydrothermal stability as evidenced from 27Al NMR analysis of the hydrothermally aged specimens [58]. Furthermore, alkali cocation introduction also enhances low-temperature NOx conversion rates since these cocations act as Lewis acids thus providing a beneficial NH3 storage function [58]. However, this study is largely only proof-of-concept in nature on cocation effects. More work is needed to explore synergies between cocations and Cu(II) ions in order to optimize such bi-cationic or even tri-cationic systems. For example, it has not been established that at industrial relevant Cu loadings (e.g., 2–3 wt%), or for SSZ-13 substrates with other Si/Al ratios, alkali cocations still provide beneficial roles, or become detrimental since they potentially compete for the same extra-framework cationic positions as Cu ions. From discussions in Section 4.3, mobility of small CuO clusters can be considered as the primary cause of structural instability for Cu/SSZ-13 [17]. In contrast, larger FexOy clusters do not appear to be as destructive [33]. It is possible, therefore, hydrothermal stability of Cu/SSZ-13 can be further enhanced by introducing a metal oxide component with high affinity toward CuO, either to the Chabazite pores, or to the external surfaces that effectively “trap” CuO formed during hydrothermal aging. If successful, then high Cu loaded catalysts with high densities of [Cu(OH)]+-Z sites, preferred for low-temperature NOx reduction, can be used with less concern about their long-term instability. This research direction is largely unexplored. 5.3 Development of new Cu/zeolite SCR catalysts From Cu/ZSM-5 to Cu/Beta [47] to Cu/Chabazite [4,6,7,59,60], research in zeolite based SCR catalysts has been driven by durability requirements for application. Despite its great performance and durability, Cu/SSZ-13 is at present only used for mobile source NOx reduction. For stationary sources (e.g., in coal-fired power plants), Cu/SSZ-13 has not been used because of its much higher cost in comparison to oxide-based SCR catalysts. Research on discovering low cost but robust zeolite based SCR catalysts is readily justified and is being pursued. Since small pore zeolites are in general hydrothermally more robust than medium and large pore zeolites [5], future research is expected to still focus on small pore zeolites. To our knowledge, the most successful catalyst beyond Cu/SSZ-13 is a high silica Cu/LTA catalyst developed by Nam, Hong and coworkers, which can even survive at hydrothermal aging temperatures 50–100 ºC higher than Cu/SSZ-13 [61–63]. The origin for this enhanced stability is not clearly known. In one study, the authors utilized Rietveld analysis to suggest that Cu(II) ions are only located in windows of 6MR [62]. On the basis of our understanding about the high hydrothermal stability of the same structure in Cu/SSZ-13, this may provide a good explanation to the remarkable stability for Cu/LTA. However, Rietveld analysis, as a bulk technique, does not always provide precise local structures for Cu ions [6]. Indeed in another study, the authors proposed that some Cu(I) ions are located in sod cages of the material, and are largely inaccessible to gaseous molecules [63]. The dual site occupation for Cu ions in LTA has been corroborated by the unexpected discovery that low-temperature SCR performance of Cu/LTA enhances after an aging treatment at 900 ºC, due to Cu migration from inaccessible to accessible locations [63]. Although not specified by the authors, we anticipate that these isolated Cu(I) ions may serve to enhance the hydrothermal stability of Cu/LTA since their isolation from water attack would render them isolated during hydrothermal aging without converting to the structural destructive CuO cluster species. We are unaware of other Cu/zeolites with much improved activity and stability than Cu/SSZ-13 at present. However, breakthroughs are expected given the current strong global enthusiasm in Cu/zeolite SCR catalysis research. 6 Conclusions Hydrothermal aging induced Cu/SSZ-13 SCR catalyst degradation, in particular dealumination and transformation of SCR active isolated Cu(II) ions to SCR inactive CuO clusters, are described. Dealumination is negligible at aging temperatures of 600 ºC and lower, but becomes more severe at higher temperatures. On the basis of quantifications with EPR, [Cu(OH)]+-Z transforms into thermodynamically more stable Cu2+-2Z, or agglomerates to CuO clusters. Sizes and locations of CuO clusters are still poorly understood. Their undetectability with STEM and lack of surface segregation indicate that these are extremely small, and locate in CHA pores and channels. Detached Al appears to interact with CuO clusters during hydrothermal aging, however to extents much earlier than CuAl2O4 spinel formation. Dealumination may contribute to degradation of the SSZ-13 substrate, however via detailed pore analysis from Ar absorption isotherm, mesopore generation from CuO cluster migration should be ultimately responsible for structural collapse of this catalyst. This is consistent with the fact that high Cu loading and high Si/Al ratio are detrimental to hydrothermal stability. In both cases, CuO formation is more facile than catalysts with low to intermediate Cu loadings and relatively low Si/Al ratios. Such atomic-level understanding leads to a few rational design concepts that minimize CuO formation during hydrothermal aging. Low-temperature NOx removal strategies, including development of new low-temperature (150 ºC) efficient SCR systems and PNA materials, are briefly introduced. Development of alternative Cu/zeolite catalysts, i.e., Cu/LTA, is also briefly described. coredata.dc:description: Cu/SSZ-13 SCR catalysts have been extensively studied in the past decade or so. Hydrothermal stability of these catalysts has been identified as the most important criterion for application. In this perspective, we describe recent atomic-level understanding of their hydrothermal stability. In particular, electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) is shown to rather accurately quantify isolated Cu(II) ions and CuO clusters in fresh and aged catalysts to demonstrate the remarkable hydrothermal stability for Cu2+ ions located in 6-membered ring windows, and the conversion of [Cu(OH)]+ ions in Chabazite cages to CuO clusters. The hydrothermal stability difference of the two isolated Cu(II) ions is confirmed with DFT simulations and the conversion of [Cu(OH)]+ to CuO is proposed to involve formation, migration and condensation of Cu(OH)2 intermediates. The structural destructive role of CuO clusters is attributed to mesopore formation from their migration, which more severely damages the catalysts than dealumination. Finally, perspectives are given on new strategies for low-temperature NOx removal, rational design and refinement of Cu/SSZ-13, and development of new Cu/zeolite SCR catalysts with even better performance than the state-of-the-art Cu/SSZ-13.
coredata.dc:title: On the hydrothermal stability of Cu/SSZ-13 SCR catalysts
